There has been a lack of self-confidence in considering the opportunities which will be offered to the City of London, which is an enormous producer of foreign exchange. At the moment we face controls over capital movements, and so on, which are in contravention of the Treaty of Rome and the Treaty of Accession.
Whatever the short-term technical arguments about delaying our joining of the proposed EMS, it surely is a matter of common sense and political or value judgment that the long-term advantages to the most sophisticated financial institution in Europe—I refer to the various aspects of the City of London—must be glittering, but are cluttered up by the threat that we shall be half in and half out of the proposed European monetary system. If we are to be half in and half out for even a short time the situation will be only too reminiscent of the time when we tried to erect a scaffolding of a larger free trade area round a hard-core Common Market, 15 to 20 years ago, and fell between all possible stools.
This is essentially a political decision. Some scathing references have been made to the origins of the movement towards European union, towards the direct con-
ciliation in the beginning between France and Germany and, even going further back in my own European pantheon, to Churchill's phrase—that France should take Germany by the hand and lead her back into the family of nations. I regret these scathing references. The negotiations—the deal struck at Messina—was based on a wish to get away from the internecine wars which had ravished this Continent twice in a lifetime and three times in 100 years. This proposal for a European monetary system must be seen in this context, of the European ideal; and without the European ideal it is meaningless just to talk about the monetary system as a technical deal.

Like my hon. Friend the Member for Nantwich (Mr. Cockcroft), I wish to speak in favour of the European monetary system and our joining it fully at its inception. Like other hon. Members who have attended the debate for nearly nine hours, it is difficult for me at this late hour to find a great deal of originality to add to the comments which have already been made so eloquently by a great number of my hon. Friends.
It is an additional disappointment that the people responsible on both Front Benches for influencing these decisions most directly have also disappeared, but perhaps I can turn my attention on the hon. Member for Newton (Mr. Evans) and at least persuade him, with all the powers at my disposal, of the desirability of this system. After all, the Government have said that this is the opportunity for Back-Bench Members to say what they feel about this question. Although the hour is late and although there are not many Members here, I want my voice to be added to the large number who have spoken in favour of the system.
This has been an extraordinary debate from the point of view of the arguments deployed by the opponents of EMS, for a number of hon. Members, particularly on the Left wing of the Labour Party—I think of the hon. Members for Sheffield, Heeley (Mr. Hooley) and for Newham, South (Mr. Spearing)—have argued in favour of the desirability of the free market process in currencies. They have deployed arguments against transfer resources, against aid—all the things which
ordinarily they are the first to cry for and, in terms of the free market, the first they criticise. Yet on this occasion, apparently objectively, they raise the virtues and the arguments against these proposals as a means of arriving at a conclusion against EMS. This is yet another example of the way in which prejudice is rationalised by the anti-Marketeers. I strongly believe that we should not put too much faith in the vociferous comments that we have heard from some of them this evening.
The changed situation within recent years makes EMS a particularly attractive proposition. I was persuaded by the theoretical advantages of floating currencies a decade or so ago. I believe that not only the considerable wash of money now going around the world but the concentrations of that huge increase in money in a few hands—whether of individuals, companies or countries—has meant that a number of currencies are particularly vulnerable to sudden movement, and on a day-to-day basis. The day-to-day movements in the exchange value of sterling over the past year have shown remarkable increases over the volatility that might have been expected a decade or so ago when we were floating.
It is this day-to-day volatility and the uncertainty that it undoubtedly causes to traders and those whose businesses we rely upon as a trading country that makes me believe that any means of promoting stability in currencies can only be in their favour, and therefore in the national interest.
In the past we have had experience of the disadvantages and the problems of a fully fixed regime. We have seen the apparent and emerging problems associated with a fully floating regime. What EMS is doing is going half way. It is in between the two. It will provide for adjustment. While the technical provisions of the scheme have been described to some extent, it is clear, as the hon. Member for Motherwell and Wishaw (Dr. Bray) pointed out, that a great deal of the technicality has not yet been decided upon. It is up to the Government, and within their ability, to ensure that their objectives in assuring that there is an adequate degree of adjustment for the currency, and no great threat on the reserve outlay by any member State, can
be observed within the rules of any scheme that is eventually finalised.
It is very important that we play our part in the international responsibility to provide a more stable international framework for monetary stability, and monetary payments and settlements. Obviously, in recent years we have seen dramatic changes in this regime because of the substantial increase in the price of oil, and more recently because of the decline in the dollar and the uncertainty and lack of confidence that that has caused. Also, the dogged recession has affected nearly all countries.
We must play our part, as the Prime Minister recognised in the Gracious Speech. That means that we must contribute to international efforts to restore confidence in the reserve currencies of an increasing number of countries which rely on trade for their aspirations in future.
I am a proponent of a confederal system for Europe in due course, and I see the EMS as the first step towards the eventual desirable aim of a common currency and full monetary and economic union. My vision of a confederation rather than a federation provides for a large degree of autonomy remaining in the hands of member States. A common currency based on the largest trading block in the world would be an immense encouragement to international trade and the aspirations of member States. The arguments for it are as much political as economic. For this reason I see EMS as a desirable first step towards it.
I recognise that, depending on the strictness of the parity system operated within EMS, there may well be pressures on some of the currencies from time to time. It may well be that a dramatic change in international events will break up that system. But this is an effort to pull ourselves together. It may be a first step on the road towards a common currency and full monetary union within Europe, and to this extent it is desirable. We have nothing to fear from observing the best monetary practices of our European partners. This is one of the best arguments in favour of it.
For all these reasons I believe that we should take a great political step forward. We should not, on this occasion, allow the faint-hearted or the technicians to stand in our way. Like many people in
this country I have been infuriated and frustrated by the stream of petty measures and directives from Europe trying to harmonise everything from the noise from lawnmowers to company law. But here, for the first time, is a real chance to take a great step forward and advance the European ideal.
I believe that many people in our party and in the country as a whole will look upon this as a litmus test of our commitment to Europe and its advancement. For those reasons, I believe that we should join the system and ensure that we are in at its inception, at the beginning of next year.

It is in some ways fitting and symbolic that this debate is ending on a high note, in terms of quality. If I may anticipate the remarks of my hon. Friends who may succeed in catching the eye of the Chair, it is a debate that is ending with a succession of contributions in favour of our joining the European monetary system.
The beginning of the debate was characterised by the opposite line, mainly from the Labour Benches but also in one or two contributions from the Opposition Benches. If I may say so without sounding offensive to colleagues who have been here longer, the elderly view—I use the expression in the wider sense—of our inability fully to participate in this great European venture has been replaced by a more modern and up-to-date view.
I refer particularly to the skilful speech of my hon. friend the Member for Carshalton (Mr. Forman) on the complicated but persuasive reasons why we should go in, despite the obvious difficulties. We all feel a natural affection and respect for the Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster whenever he speaks in the House, but on this occasion we also felt a great deal of sympathy for him, because it was clear that he was wholeheartedly in favour of our joining the EMS without any delay, yet, because of the peculiar and equivocal line that the Cabinet is taking, he could not bring himself officially to admit that.
What a difference there was between the right hon. Gentleman's temptation to go further and say all that and the Chancellor of the Exchequer's equivocal atti-
tude. What a pity it is that the Chancellor of the Exchequer could not take a bolder attitude with his colleagues.
I know that it is late and that the debate has gone on for some time, but it is a pity that there is no Minister on duty. I hope that the hon. Member for Newton (Mr. Evans), a dedicated Whip, will make a careful note of what is said and make sure that Ministers pay attention to what appears in Hansard. It would be all too easy for them to go away reflecting on the comments made earlier. There were reactionary comments and some disgraceful comments, including those made by the right hon. Member for Blackburn (Mrs. Castle), about the German urge to dominate us yet again, and all that nonsense.
We heard a disgraceful and absurd speech by the right hon. Member for Down, South (Mr. Powell), which might unduly affect the debate. I hope not. It was a speech by a right hon. Gentleman whose view about the whole European exercise was encapsulated only a few weeks ago in the inspiring sentiment that really the Germans hated us still because we had won the war in 1945 and the French had never forgiven us not only for not supporting them over Algérie Francaise but because we had beaten Napoleon.
I suspect that the right hon. Gentleman is the leader of a diminishing range of opinions and people in this country and Ulster. But it is absurd for anyone who is apparently a leader of opinion to come out with such reactionary statements about the EMS and its apparent disadvantages. I am glad that on this occasion he just failed to end with the usual"Beware, Britain ", and so on. He spared us that, but the rest of his speech was wholly deplorable.
The other reasons for supporting the EMS are cogent and pressing, but I find the right hon. Gentleman's reactionary attitude reason enough to say that there must be something in the EMS.
The reasons for going in are partly political and partly economic. They are of course mainly political, but the two go side by side. It would be tragic if we again missed—we have done it again and again—a vital opportunity to join an imaginative scheme. It has many wrinkles and problems, but they can be worked out afterwards, and we should
join on the first day. The intention is still that that should be 1st January, if the summit can take the proper decision next week.
The reasons are manifold. I shall mention only one or two. If France, proud of her sovereignty and independence, even though a member of the Community —the two things are not contradictory —can do it, so can we. If Italy, with problems of inflation, currency vulnerability verging on the critical still and, I suppose, the most ferocious exchange control regime of all the European countries can go in immediately—and all the indications are that she will—so can we.
The idea that was highlighted in the report of the General Sub-Committee that we still had very special problems as a reserve currency was a gross exaggeration of the role of sterling, which has now declined. Of course, it is still a reserve currency, and more than just technically, but to say that the scope of the problem is so onerous and enormous that we are in a special position is very similar to what we hear from the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, who was rightly denounced after the collapse of the last fisheries talks by one Minister, who said that it was amazing how the British still thought they had an empire.
Another argument advanced in the Sub-Committee's report was that the United Kingdom would have to run a lower than average inflation rate. Is not that what this country's objective is, anway? What is the purpose of all the counter-inflation policy pursued by the present Government if it is not to do just that? Membership of the EMS would give us not only a practical obligation and a moral obligation but a technical obligation to pursue a deliberate policy to maintain not only a"strong"currency but a lower-than-average inflation rate than anything that we have had in recent years. Having got the inflation rate down at long last to about 8 per cent., surely the proposal must be welcomed overwhelmingly by all sensible opinion.
I also take issue with the comment in the Sub-Committee's report that United Kingdom exchange controls are more severe than those of other EEC countries. Italy is the obvious example against that case. I think that there is a strong argument for some relaxation of exchange
controls as soon as possible, but it is also in order to say that we cannot do it overnight, and certainly not at the beginning of the EMS.
I may be the only speaker in this debate to refer to the other document which we are considering, R/2790/1/78, dealing with the technical aspects of the creation of the ECU and the European Monetary Co-operation Fund looking after that for a couple of years and being replaced by the European Monetary Fund.
It may seem almost trivial, but I ask hon. Members to imagine the advantages that would accrue to the country if the EMF were to be established, say, in two years from now and located in London. It is long overdue for this country to have a Community institution, and it would be of tremendous benefit for us to have this major new institution.
The Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster was right to say that it was no good taking the spurious economic models and the conclusions from them and saying that those were the only conclusions to be reached from any economic projections about the effect of our joining the EMS. It so happens that I arranged for a run-off to be done. If different assumptions are put in at the beginning of the Cambridge economic model, the results are quite different. The results which I obtained indicated that there would be an actual increase in employment, on the same basis as the original assumptions put in by Professor Ward, and that growth would be at least the same if we joined the EMS and might even be slightly better.
All the predictions do not add up to very much. Therefore, this is an effort of will—a decision of will—and it is high politics. On balance, I think that the economic advantages will outweigh the disadvantages. I think that the majority opinion in this country is agreeable to our joining an imaginative new scheme, which I regret to say the Germans and the French are at present leading on their own, where we should be, too, to form a troika of leadership in the Community. Therefore, I hope that although the Government are fainthearted, pusillanimous and equivocal now, they will change their mind in due time and join this scheme before it is too late.

This is a time for brevity, so I shall discard 95 per cent. of what I was going to say. I came to this debate seeking answers to three questions. First, would it be better for Britain to go into EMS or to stay out? Secondly, if the answer is to go in, what sort of concessions do we need and how shall we get them? Thirdly, if the answer is to stay out, how shall we manage outside in the cold?
The Chancellor of the Exchequer did not answer any of those questions. Instead of illumination, we received a display of econometric simulation. My right hon. and learned Friend the Member for Surrey, East (Sir G. Howe) went somewhat further. He spoke of our unreserved belief in the need for greater monetary stability and said that we were for, not against, the EMS, although he wisely wanted assurances on a number of subjects, in particular the transfer of resources. But he still left me in the dark.
That is why I am very glad to have sat through the whole debate, because my heart leapt up when I heard my right hon. and learned Friend the Member for Hexham (Mr. Rippon) state clearly that the Conservative Party is in favour of our joining the EMS, provided that we can get the necessary protections for our national interest. That is the approach that he adopted during the negotiations for our entry of the Community in the first place, it is the right approach now, and I am glad that he made that clear.
I was pleased, indeed, relieved, by the speech of the Chancellor of the Duchy, who redeemed the flat and uninspired speech of the Chancellor of the Exchequer.
So I come to the end of the debate with my questions not entirely answered but reasonably satisfied that the Opposition at least would join the EMS, subject to satisfactory assurances. I fear that the Government will not do so; they will prove faint-hearted. My right hon. and learned Friend the Member for Hexham was right to quote the French proverb, that the absent are always wrong. I was brought up to believe that it is nearly always best to be there. We shall do far better for our country and for Europe if we get involved at the beginning and
debate the details as full members of this new system than if we remain on the outside, hoping to get concessions after the others have made their agreement.
It is right to take the decision in principle and to argue the details afterwards, rather than to be caught carping, worrying, destroying, before we make up our minds.
I was disappointed by the speech of the Chancellor of the Exchequer, I was relieved by the speech of my right hon. and learned Friend the Member for Hexham, and the Chancellor of the Duchy at least has given us some cause to believe that, although they will jib at taking the decision on 1st January, sooner or later, because they have sane men in their midst, the Government will reach the conclusion put forward by my right hon. and learned Friend.

The House has been considering the effect of EMS on the country as a whole and, in particular, on our economic and financial life. I know that the hour is late, but I have been waiting a long time and I want to probe the effect of EMS on agriculture and food. This is of great interest, not only to farmers but to all in the food processing industry.
I regret that no Minister is in the House. I have many questions that I wish to ask. I hope that I shall receive answers on another occasion. I was also disappointed in the Green Paper, because it contains nothing about the effect on the CAP. The CAP is one of the major achievements of the Community. This matter should be probed, and that is what I intend to do, in spite of the late hour.
This is a complicated subject. It is difficult to have a clear picture. Economists give different views about the agriculture aspect of the issue. Agriculture and the food industry want what is best for Great Britain as a whole. They realise that they cannot prosper if the economy is in trouble. Unemployment, lower wages and inflation are no friends of agriculture and the food industry. Inflation is still the real enemy. If EMS becomes a reality and helps to curb inflation it must be right to go ahead. It will certainly help agriculture and the food industry.
I am no expert, but it seems that EMS will exert real discipline on the country. In the long term that cannot be bad. It seems that it will bring stability. From an agricultural view that is a real plus. For too long, as green pound devaluations have taken place, erosion of the pound has brought us back to where we started, or perhaps further back. This happened in 1978. If stability comes, agriculture would surely welcome it.
I understand that the range of fluctuations allowable without alteration to MCAs would be wider. That is another plus. It would be 4½ per cent. instead of the present 1½ per cent. If a Minister were in the Chamber, as he should be, I should be able to have an answer to that question. It is sad that that cannot be.
The system would not be as variable as it is now. Today, fluctuations occur weekly. Anyone who is in the food processing business, or who is buying in from other parts of the world, knows that the weekly change causes many problems.
What is the position of MCAs in the concept of EMS? What is the position of the green pound? Are we locked into a situation because of EMS? Fears have been expressed, and they should be dealt with. The green pound gap is now 30 per cent. Will it become higher? I understand that the pound might be devalued if we joined the EMS in January. The gap would then be much higher than 30 per cent. It might range up to 35 per cent. or 36 per cent. That would be serious for British agriculture. The fear of being locked in is an important factor. The Minister should make it quite clear that we want changes not in the concept of the CAP, but in its internal working. It is important that the fear that changes cannot be made should be dealt with.
We do not know whether the adoption of the EMS would be accompanied by the adoption of the EUA, the new basket of currencies of account. That would have an enormous effect on MCAs throughout the Community. It has been said that at the present level the current British negative MCA would be reduced from minus 30.8 per cent. to minus 6 per cent., while the German positive MCA would be increased equally sharply from 10.8 per cent. to 25.7 per cent. That is a significant change, and would avoid the
problem of having common prices in the long run. The gap would be very small—down to about 6 per cent. We would have have liked the Minister to give his views on this, with an assurance on the question whether my views are correct.
The unfairness of the subsidies that spring from the MCAs would be on the way out. That would make things fair for the British producer. It would certainly help the long-suffering processors who deal with pigmeat.
If the Irish Republic joint EMS and we do not, the separation of the pound sterling and the Irish pound would mean a permanent and larger distortion in agricultural trade between the two countries. This would be a serious matter, because British agriculture already suffers from the differences between the United Kingdom and the Republic.
I believe that we should make this step, and that we should take it seriously. I hope that it can be accompanied by internal changes in the CAP. Surely it is possible, if we join the EMS as I want, to get a firm guarantee of changes in the internal workings of the policy. That would be a considerable plus for the Community.
I hope that this country will not be shown once more to be dithering. I believe that the objectives of the EMS are right. Agriculture will acquire stability. I hope we shall move towards EMS, because in the long run it will greatly benefit British agriculture and its food producers.

The only point in intervening at this stage is to ensure that the record reflects the growing weight of opinion, as the debate has proceeded, in favour of joining the EMS, culminating in the magnificent speech of my right hon. and learned Friend the Member for Hexham (Mr. Rippon). I caught again some of the echoes of the heroic age of the combat for a united Europe in what I thought was one of the finest speeches he has delivered from the Front Bench.
I am, however, bound to take account of the remarkable speech of my hon. Friend the Member for Croydon, Central (Mr. Moore). It impressed all those who heard it. My hon. Friend advanced
many carefully considered arguments against EMS in its present form. Convincing though his arguments were, the fact is that EMS will come into existence. It will be brought into existence by Chancellor Schmidt and President Giscard d'Estaing. It is surely wrong to assume that either of those statesmen is impractical or anti-European. It would be wrong to assume that their policies are designed to damage the interests of the poorer nations, whether poorer nations within the Community or in the Third world.
I shall make my speech briefly. Britain is part of the EEC. It would have been possible for us not to have joined. Some argue that we would have been better off if we had not, although I profoundly disagree with that view. What is beyond discussion is that it is no longer practically possible for us to leave the EEC. It would be legally but not practically possible to leave it. We cannot stand alone. There is nowhere else that we can go. Once we had shown ourselves to be hopelessly undependable, nobody else would want us.
The EEC is not working well. That is one thing. It is not working to our advantage, and that is quite another thing. However, the two factors are connected. It is not working well because each member State puts its own interests, even short-term or secondary interests, before vital long-term interests and the long-term interests of the Community as a whole. No nation has been more at fault in that respect than the United Kingdom under its present Government.

The hon. Gentleman says that the EEC is not working well. Does he agree that one of the causes for that is the rather—to quote a word used in the House not so long ago—" viscous"quality of the EEC institutions? Decisions take a long time. They have to be agreed by nine representatives in various committees. That is a bad way in which to run a government.

That is so. That is why I want to see more effective institutional machinery within the EEC and better machinery for arriving at decisions. In addition, there has to be a greater readiness on the part of member States to subordinate their secondary or short-term
interest to the long-term interests of the Community as a whole.
That leads me to my next argument. There are a great many hon. Members who, disliking the EEC, invariably say that none the less they wish to see more international co-operation. Whether we are in the EEC or out of it, we cannot have international co-operation unless those who want to co-operate are prepared to sacrifice some of their own national interests. All that the EEC does is to set up machinery—it might be more effective than it is—to ensure that the minimum sacrifice by each member State produces the maximum good for the Community as a whole. That is what the Community is about. It is institutionalised co-operation.
The only part of the EEC that is working fully—and it is not working well—is the common agricultural policy. The policy was formulated before we became a member of the EEC and its whole concept is contrary to our interests—at any rate, our short-term interests. As the CAP is the only working policy of the EEC, it absorbs the lion's share of the budget. As we had no part in drafting it we have had little success in changing it to reduce our contribution.
If we want to do better out of the EEC, the best way is not to try to cut down its activities. We would have little support if we made that attempt. On the contrary, the best way is to extend the range of EEC activities into areas where we may reasonably hope to gain from effective Community action. If, for example, we were to take the lead in formulating a common energy policy, we could be pretty sure of constructing a policy that would be in our interests.
It is in that spirit that I approach EMS. The technical considerations are, of course, important. They can tell us how much it would cost us in real terms to join the EMS, how long before we could hope for any advantage, and how great, if any, that advantage would be. I shall deal with these technical consideration. First, it is said, the EMS will be set up; secondly, it will become a more important feature of the EEC than the common agricultural policy; thirdly, if we do not join it as founder members it will operate gravely to our disadvantage: fourthly, as time goes on it will become harder for us
to join and the consequences of not joining will become more serious; and, fifthly, we cannot possibly afford to join it now.
This chain of argument spells inexorable decline. We have to try to break out of the vicious circle at some point. We cannot hope to block the EMS, nor should we want to do so, since it offers one of the few hopes of averting a disastrous world slump, touched off by competitive devaluations and import restrictions. If we are outside the EMS, the Common Market will continue to develop more to our disadvantage, although the impossibility of leaving it will remain as absolute as ever. Once the EMS is set up without us, the chances of influencing it more to our taste will be worse than they have been with the CAP. Indeed, after the fiasco of the Labour Party's much-vaunted renegotiation of 1974, such chances are nil.
There is only one way out, and that is to join now and to seek to influence the system from within, before its policies have set hard. I do not quarrel with the Government's using every method to improve their bargaining position. The trouble is that the activities of the Secretary of State for Energy and the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food have raised a serious doubt about our good faith as partners, while the indecent eagerness with which the Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs seeks to disavow his former commitment to Europe does little to predispose our EEC partners towards us. Our bargaining position is weak. The best tactic, as well as the best strategy, is enthusiastically to welcome and support what we have no choice but to join, the more so since joining it will be greatly to our advantage.
I beg to ask leave to withdraw the motion.
Motion made, and Question proposed, That this House do now adjourn.—[Mr. John Evans.]

I am grateful for the opportunity provided by this Adjournment debate to raise the
question of the problems of protecting householders against subsidence. I have had a particularly had example of subsidence affecting a comparatively new housing estate at Wivenhoe in my constituency, where the houses are only four to five years old. This case has attracted a considerable amount of publicity, both in the press and on television. There are 56 houses on the estate and the insurance companies, acting on a report prepared by a consulting engineer with considerable experience, have paid out on 19 houses. Since then the National House Building Council has commissioned another consulting engineer to prepare another report.
I have been sent the second report but, in spite of promises from the National House Building Council, I have not been sent a copy of the first report made by Mr. Burt, the consulting engineer first employed to report on the subsidence. The second report is, I am told, much more optimistic than the first one. Following the second report, the National House Building Council tells me that the insurance companies have been persuaded to renew subsidence cover and, in the words of the NHBC: Building societies are to be informed, in the hope that valuers will respond favourably. The National House Building Council says that it plans to landscape the estate and carry out the work designed to make the occupied houses safe and habitable once more. It is prepared to give new 10-year certificates on the houses. Nevertheless, the insurance companies have paid out on 19 of the 56 houses on the estate following the first report and, with the adverse publicity in the press and television, quite understandably, a blight has descended on the remaining houses on the estate.
If any of the householders on the estate wish to sell their houses it is unlikely that they will be able to get more than two-thirds of the correct capital value which they would have been able to obtain had subsidence not occurred. A great many of these householders are management executives, for whom mobility is extremely important. Already one householder has had a sale fall through because of what has happened. He is now having to work 200 miles away from his family home at Wivenhoe and now faces most disturbing family problems.
I have been in touch with the householders, the local council, the National House Building Council, and Mr. Burt, the the author of the first report. I have paid several visits to the estate, the last one being this previous weekend. I find the householders far from satisfied. Indeed, they are very disturbed by what has happened and are in a mood to challenge the second report, in spite of the offers which have now been made by the National House Building Council to give a 10-year guarantee on these houses so that mortgages can be obtained from the building societies and the houses reinsured.
I am told by the householders that Dr. Henkel, the author of the second report, was not allowed to go into any of the houses by the householders because the National House Building Council would not let them see a copy of the first report. Indeed, the householders still have a great deal of scepticism about what has happened and are fearful of the present position because of the blight that has been caused. They told me last weekend that new cracks were appearing.
The Colchester district council, which has been left holding the baby, as it were, after local government reorganisation, has been most helpful. It has done everything it can to keep me informed about what is happening and is naturally concerned about what has occurred. Like me, it has already asked for a public inquiry.
I must respect the good faith of the National House Building Council and thank it for having given £59,000 to top up some of the householders who were under-insured, and for the new guarantees which have been given. But, bearing in mind what has happened, and knowing the feeling of the householders, I doubt whether it will be enough to help in this situation, particularly in the light of the further reports that I have received. I have spoken to Mr. Burt, and in spite of the fact that he has signed the second report, I must comment, having heard what he has to say, that I am far from happy about the situation.
I have had a report this evening about a house on the estate which has just been put on the market by a firm of local estate agents. In spite of the National House Building Council's guarantees, it
has sent a letter to the owners of the house saying that the house is unmortgageable, uninsurable and consequently unsaleable, so at the moment my estimate of two-thirds of the previous capital value is wrong. Indeed, I have heard this evening that 150 yards off the estate, in Parkwood Avenue, the insurers now refuse to insure without a £200 structural engineer's survey and report. Curing the blight, therefore, will be a slow and uphill progress.
This brings me to a consideration of what, practically, can be done to help these householders. I have just had a letter from the secretary-general of the British Insurance Association, speaking about the United Kingdom as a whole, and saying that the average cost of repairs to a house that has suffered subsidence is about £3,000. It is estimated that insurance claims for subsidence since 1951 in the United Kingdom have amounted to about £100 million. The secretary-general says that A significant factor is that building has taken place in unsuitable sites, for example, on gravel pits, old coal and clay mine workings and steep hillsides and railway embankments. The British Insurance Association hopes that the Department of the Environment will give guidance to local authorities on the subject of land available for property development and establish a much tougher policy towards this matter. Indeed, some of the pamphlets coming from the Department at the present time signify this, but it does not help the householders in their present situation.
Because of the circumstances that I have outlined, which I heard about as long as six months ago, the local council and I have been pressing for a public inquiry to be held as soon as possible into what has happened at Wivenhoe. There is extreme doubt in people's minds whether planning permission should ever have been given for the site. Has the Minister seen the reports of the district surveyor about the site? Bearing in mind what has happened, we are interested to know what was reported and what the architects say about the site and what has happened there.
Is enough care taken to examine filled-in sites? That is the purport of what the secretary-general of the British Insurance Association wrote to me. From what has happened at Wivenhoe, it seems that
not enough care is taken. In September 1978, the Department of the Environment published a paper on the foundations of low-rise building. It is claimed by many of the householders that the conditions of building in-fill outlined in the paper have not been met in this case. Obviously the contradictory reports of two consulting engineers must be considered as well, though there is now a joint repor
Help has been given by the NHBC, but the council is not and nor are the insurance companies able to give help in respect of blight. The NHBC has told owners that they must realise that they have no legal right of compensation. I regard that as most unsatisfactory. The value of sound houses on the estate is substantially less than it would be ordinarily. In spite of the NHBC guarantees the fact that mortgages are available to buy sound houses and the fact that the other houses are to be rehabilitated, the blight will remain for some time.
Many householders will be several thousand pounds out of pocket, through no fault of their own, if they wish to move. Indeed, if the report that I have just received is correct, it may be much more than that. Obviously the fact that insurance companies have paid out on 19 of the 56 houses on the estate leads one to conclude that it is problematical whether planning permission should have been given for the estate or a substantial part of it. If that is so, the local council or its successor must bear a considerable responsibility for what has happened.
A public inquiry will be a long and slow process. Urgent action is needed to help the remaining householders at Wivenhoe, which is only one example of what is happening on other estates throughout the country. That help can be given only if the local council—in this case the Colchester district council—considers, after examining all the facts, that faulty planning permission was granted and is willing to accept full responsibility, buy from those who wish to sell and, in due time, rehabilitate the estate as the NHBC says may be possible. That is the way of common sense.
I hope that the Minister will look at the matter urgently. This is a most unfair case, and I feel sure that there are bound to be others. My hon. Friend the Mem-
ber for Bury St. Edmunds (Mr. Griffiths) will outline a similar case in his constituency. Something must be done immediately to protect householders against blight in such cases.
While pressing for a public inquiry, I am looking for other, more urgent, action and for the local council to accept responsibility at once, bearing in mind, especially, the doubt that must exist over the granting of planning permission in the first place.
I hope that the Minister will be able to announce that a public inquiry will be held and that action will be taken to help overcome the serious blight and the serious worry caused to many householders, who are in the executive class and must have mobility of labour and should be able to move around, but are prevented from doing so through no fault of their own, but through bad planning.

The people of Wivenhoe are very fortunate to have my hon. Friend the Member for Harwich (Mr. Ridsdale) as their Member. He takes a diligent interest in all these problems, and he has done his constituents, and indeed the House of Commons, a service by raising this matter even at this very late hour.
I wish to mention a similar case, and I apologise to the Minister for not having been able to give him full notice of the facts. I refer to Jacqueline Close, Bury St. Edmunds, which suffered severe subsidence a few years ago. Planning permission was given by the local authority, the builder put up two rows of attractive homes, 20 to 30 families moved in, and in a matter of months the houses began to subside.
Underneath the site were some spectacular old chalk workings, which had been dug out during the First World War. The water from the roofs of the new construction had loosened the chalk, displacing some of the foundations. The consequences were alarming. The houses began to slip into deep holes. I went down into some of these caverns. It was an astonishing sight.
For the builder in the first instance it was a financial disaster. He was unable to sell a significant number of the houses
and he did not get his money for some of those already occupied. For the residents—the purchasers—it was a catastrophe. Most lost a good deal of their savings. Nearly all of them lost their homes and then faced the problem of what was to be done. The first question was, and is: was the planning permission wrong in the first place? The local authority denied this, and I do not doubt its good faith. But I have no doubt that it was within the collective knowledge of the council at that time that there had been old chalk workings underneath that site. The authority should perhaps have known, but certainly it had some responsibility to the builder and the residents for what happened.
The second point concerns the blighting that arose in that neighbourhood for a considerable period. In the event, I remember proposing that a compulsory purchase order be made because of the public health hazard that had arisen. After a long time a CPO finally has been made and the council has taken this derelict site into its own possession. In the meantime, several years have passed, there have been great distress and loss to ordinary people. That is unacceptable.
I hope that the Minister will say that where councils give planning permission and where those who, in good faith, build on that land find that there is subsidence for other reasons, which should have been made known in the first instance, responsibility should lie on the local authority to make good some of the losses suffered by innocent people.

speech.speakername: The Under-Secretary of State for the Environment (Mr. Ernest Armstrong)
speech.p:
The hon. Member for Harwich (Mr. Rids-dale) has raised a serious issue, which I know has caused great disturbance and distress to many people on the estate at Wivenhoe. The hon. Member for Bury St. Edmunds (Mr. Griffiths) has properly drawn attention to the distress caused in his area.
As a Member who represents Durham, I must tell the hon. Gentleman that we are undermined, as it were, as we have widespread coal mining operations. I have great experience of the distress that can be caused by subsidence.
As I understand it, the estate of 56 houses was developed about five years ago, the necessary planning and building regulation consents being given by the then Wivenhoe urban district council. The site originally included a valley with a stream running along the bottom. This valley had been filled with tipped material about 10 years before development began. About half the houses were built on the filled area and a number have now suffered cracking and damage to their foundations.
A number of questions arise—the first and most important of which, I am sure we all agree, is whether there is any real danger to life. In this connection I understand that the council now responsible—Colchester district council—has rehoused the occupants of the houses that it considered to be at risk. The council's insurers have commissioned a survey of the estate, and its results will be considered by the council as soon as they are available. If any further action is necessary in the interests of public health and safety, then I am sure that the council will take it.
Another issue raised is that of compensation for parties injured financially as a result of the subsidence—either directly by damage to their homes or indirectly because of the difficulty that they face in selling and moving away. This financial question is initially for the insurance companies and the National House Building Council.
I understand that the insurance companies and the NHBC acted to enable all the owners affected to move out of their homes. Where householders were underinsured, the NHBC"topped up"insurance settlements of £206,000 with payments totalling £59,000, as the hon. Gentleman mentioned.
The remaining houses on the estate were blighted following reports that there was a danger of further damage. The NHBC commissioned Ove Arup and Partners to report on the position, in association with the local engineer who first reported a potential hazard. The joint report, which I understand has been sent to the hon. Gentleman as well as to residents on the estate and, indeed, to my Department, finds that There is at the moment nowhere any sign of any occupied houses which could in any way
be considered dangerous due to foundation settlement or any cause. Where cracking of walls has taken place, the report continues, reasons other than landslip are to blame—for example, unequal loading, different properties of adjacent building materials, and so on.
The NHBC has offered the householders who are still in residence on the estate an ex-gratia payment of £100 for cosmetic repairs, and now hopes to be able to persuade insurers to give subsidence cover to the houses. The results of the joint survey are being drawn to the attention of the building societies.
I hope that these steps will help owners of the houses still occupied on this estate.
I now turn to the question whether the Secretary of State should institute a public inquiry. It has been suggested that such an inquiry should consider, among other things, the circumstances in which planning and building regulations consent were granted, the adequacy of inspections of the estate before permission was given and while the houses were under construction, the present condition of the estate, and the apportionment of responsibility for compensation.
The Secretary of State's powers to hold public inquiries under section 250 of the Local Government Act 1972 are not relevant to the Wivenhoe case. There are also powers under section 318 of the Public Health Act 1936 to hold a local inquiry in connection with certain functions exercised under that Act and in relation to any matter concerning the public health in any place. These latter powers are essentially related to questions of public health and are normally used only where an inquiry is thought the best way to ascertain facts needed to determine public hazard not limited to the case in the nature and extent of a possible general question.
I must, however, make it perfectly clear that this provides no power to award compensation to injured parties.
As far as the planning matters are concerned, I am advised that a local authority does not have responsibility under planning powers for the stability of land for development, although there are special liaison arrangements in respect of certain coalmining areas.
In the particular case at Wivenhoe, the council has taken action to deal with any immediate risk to public health or safety. The council's insurers, and the NHBC have both commissioned consultants to advise on the present state of the site, and a public inquiry would certainly not hasten progress. The sole purpose of such an inquiry would therefore seem to be to apportion responsibility, although the Secretary of State has no power to award compensation and questions arising could well be the subject of subsequent litigation.
My right hon. Friend will, of course, take account of all that the hon. Member has said, as well as the weighty arguments that I have set out in this debate, and I shall write to the hon. Member when the local authority is informed of my right hon. Friend's decision.
If my right hon. Friend decided not to hold an inquiry, that would not in any way fetter the council if it wished to arrange a public inquiry under an independent chairman.
I should make it clear that if the residents are seeking an inquiry in order to obtain more information about the state of their properties, an inquiry instituted by my right hon. Friend under section 318 of the Public Health Act 1936 would have no more power to require interested parties to divulge information against their wishes than would an inquiry instituted by the local authority.
I recognise the urgency of the matter. I shall read carefully what both hon. Gentlemen said about their views of the local authority's duties and the NHBC and a particular report. I shall discuss the matter with my right hon. Friend.
Will the Minister assure me that in arriving at his decision in the Wivenhoe case, he will have regard to the Jacqueline Close example that I mentioned, because the two are comparable?

I shall certainly get all the information available about Jacqueline Close and discuss it with my right hon. Friend. I recognise the urgency and the distress felt by people in these circumstances. I shall let the hon. Gentleman and the authority know the Secretary of State's decision as soon as possible.

Is the hon. Gentleman aware that we are concerned about the plight of these people? They wish to move, they wish to have mobility of labour, and their capital value has gone. That is the question to which we have to address our minds.
I assure the hon. Gentleman that I take on board the feelings of the people concerned.

p.i: Adjourned accordingly at nine minutes to Two o'clock.
